subject: Re: [junit] DBC
msgSnippet: Yep. The contract specifies what the class/method guarantees about its state and output given entry state. Unit tests are a tangible form of that guarantee and
messageBody:
Yep. The contract specifies what the class/method guarantees about its
state and output given entry state. Unit tests are a tangible form of that
guarantee and are, in the end, what you can actually rely on to be
correct. Design-By-Contract (provided by Eiffel, Java with iContract, or
methodical use of assertion constructs) adds the additional guarantee that
a call will not succeed if the contract is broken, making it much easier
to locate problems.

Brian Marrick makes the distinction between preconditions and checked
preconditions. There are some conditions that are required for the
contract to hold but which the method either cannot check, cannot check
efficiently, or simply elects not to check. In this case, the
results are usually given as 'undefined'. Checked preconditions on
the other hand, can be expected to signal a particular error and generally
to exit gracefully. Unit tests can and should verify that violations of
checked preconditions do, in fact, fail.

On Wed, 3 Apr 2002, David V. Olivier wrote:

> Right:
>
> - A formal contract can logically state classes of inputs and the
> corresponding results.
> - Unit tests can provide specific examples of inputs and results.
>
> The former can often be interpolated from the latter and for many purposes
> that is sufficient or even preferable. However, as you say, there are
> probably scenarios in which the more explicit statement is useful.
>
> At 08:35 AM 4/3/2002 +0200, you wrote:
>
> >Don't get me wrong I'm a big fan of JUnit and unit testing but...
> >
> >...I do regularly have problems using components, which would not have
> >occurred if there had been clearly stated pre-conditions (admittedly these
> >components don't usually come with associated unit tests).
> >Are a collection of unit tests a clear statement of the contract? I'm not
> >convinced. I do agree that by rigourously using TFD you will end up with
> >classes/methods with sweet smelling contracts. However if we consider the
> >airline metaphor which is often used for DBC: when I'm booking a ticket
> >with an airline I like to know the conditions which are attached - I don't
> >merely want a list of previous passengers and how they got on.
> >
> >Steven Hale, wm-data
